member.name: T:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvOptions
member.summary: Named constants to specify options for reading and writing CSV files. The flags can be combined.

remarks.note: To work safely and conveniently with the enum, use the extension methods of the class (see example)!

example.para: Example, which demonstrates that setting the flag can lead to unexpected results when an attempt is made to cache the result set.
example.note: In the following code example - for easier readability - exception handling was dispensed.

member.name: F:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvOptions.None
member.summary: No flag is set. This creates a very lenient parser that rarely throws exceptions.

member.name: F:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvOptions.ThrowOnTooMuchFields
member.summary:
If set throws an if a data row contains more fields than the first data row.
If a data row has more Fields than the first data row, this is a strong indication of a read error. The flag should therefore usually be set.

member.name: F:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvOptions.ThrowOnTooFewFields
member.summary:
If set throws an if a data row has less fields than the first data row.
Other software could dispense with marking empty fields at the end of a row with field separators. On the other hand, the missing of fields at the end of a row could be an indication of a read error.

member.name: F:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvOptions.ThrowOnEmptyLines
member.summary:
If set throws an if there are blank lines in the CSV file, that are not part of a data field masked with quotes.
Blank lines that are not part of a masked field can in no case be interpreted as part of the data to be read. However, by removing the flag ignores such blank lines.

member.name: F:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvOptions.CaseSensitiveKeys
member.summary: If the flag is not set the class interpretes the column names of the CSV file in a case-insensitive manner. This is the same behavior that shows.

member.name: F:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvOptions.TrimColumns
member.summary: If the flag is set and will handle all data tokens and the column names with the method. That leads to a strong loss of performance and also can damage data where the leading and trailing white space has a meaning. Only set the flag for reading non-standard CSV files, which introduce additional padding.

member.name: F:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvOptions.Default
member.summary: Default setting. This is a combined value that forces to throw an if the file to be read does not comply with the RFC 4180 standard. (Alternative column separators and newline characters are always tolerated.)

member.name: F:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvOptions.DisableCaching
member.summary: If the flag is set the same object is used for each data row when reading the CSV file (filled with new data). That brings slight performance advantages when parsing very large CSV files, but can lead to unexpected results if an attempt is made to cache the results. (see example)

member.name: T:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvReader
member.summary: Provides read-only forward access to the records of a CSV file. (This means, that the can only read the file forward once.)

remarks.para: The method returns an IEnumerator<CsvRecord> that can be used to iterate over the data records of the CSV file as objects.
The class maps the the order of the data columns of the objects at runtime to the column order of a and performs type conversions.
When reading an unknown CSV file the appropriate parameters for the constructor of can be found automatically with the help of the .

example.note: In the following code examples - for easier readability - exception handling has been omitted.
example.para: Linq query on a CSV file:
Saving the content of a as a CSV file and reading data from a CSV file into a :

member.param: File path of the CSV file.
true if the CSV file has a header with column names.

The field separator char used in the CSV file.
The text encoding to be used to read the CSV file or null for .

is not a valid file path.
The data cannot be accessed.

member.summary: Returns a IEnumerable<CsvRecord> object to iterate over the rows of the CSV file.
member.returns: An IEnumerable<CsvRecord> that can be used to iterate over the rows of the CSV file.
member.exception: The method was called more than once.

member.name: M:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvReader.Dispose
member.summary: Releases the resources. (Closes the .)

member.name: T:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvRecord
member.summary: Represents a record of the CSV file (row). The column order corresponds to that of the CSV file and all columns are of the data type . The content of the columns can be accessed using a zero-based column index or the column name.

remarks.para: The class maps the the order of the data columns of the objects at runtime to the column order of a and performs type conversions.

member.name: P:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvRecord.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets or sets the value of the column in the CSV file, which is at the specified index.
member.param: The zero-based index of the column in the CSV file whose value is being obtained or set.
member.returns: The item at the specified index.
member.exception: is less than 0 or greater than or equal to .

member.name: P:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvRecord.Item(System.String)
member.summary: Gets or sets the value associated with the specified column name in the CSV file.
member.param: The column name of the CSV file.
member.returns: The value associated with the specified column name.
member.exception: The column name specified with does not exist.
is null.

member.name: P:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvRecord.Count
member.summary: Returns the number of columns in .

member.name: P:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvRecord.IsEmpty
member.summary: Returns true if is 0 or all fields have the value null.

member.name: P:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvRecord.ColumnNames
member.summary: Returns the column names.
member.remarks: If the CSV file did not have a header, column names of the type "Column1", "Column2" etc. are automatically assigned.

member.name: P:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvRecord.Values
member.summary: Returns the collection of the data stored in . The Values can be changed.

member.name: M:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvRecord.ToDictionary
member.summary: Returns a copy of the data stored in as Dictionary<string, string?>. The dictionary uses the same for the key comparison with which was created.
member.returns: A copy of the data stored in as Dictionary<string, string?>.

member.name: M:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvRecord.Clear
member.summary: Sets all data fields of to null.

member.name: M:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvRecord.TryGetValue(System.String,System.String@)
member.summary: Gets the value associated with the specified column name in the CSV file.
member.param: The column name in the CSV file whose value is being obtained.
After the method has finished the argument contains the value associated with the column name specified with if the key was found, or null otherwise. The parameter is passed uninitialized.
member.returns: true if it contains a column name with the value of .
member.exception: is null.

member.name: M:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvRecord.TryGetValue(System.Int32,System.String@)
member.summary: Gets the value associated with the specified column index of the CSV file.
member.param: Zero-based index of the data column of the CSV file.
When this method returns the parameter contains the value assigned to the column index specified with if the column index exists, or null otherwise. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
member.returns: true if a column index with the value of exists in the CSV file.

member.name: M:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvRecord.Fill(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.String})
member.summary: Fills with the contents of a collection.
member.param: A collection.
member.exception: is null.
contains more entries than .
member.remarks: If has fewer entries than the remaining fields of are filled with null values.

member.name: M:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvRecord.ContainsColumn(System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether the object contains a column with the specified column name.
member.param: The column name of the CSV file column to search for.
member.returns: true if is one of the column names of the object.
member.exception: is null.

member.name: M:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvRecord.IndexOfColumn(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the zero-based index of the column in the CSV file, which has the specified column name, or -1 if is not one of the column names in the CSV file.
member.param: The column name to be checked for the index of that it refers to.
member.returns: The zero-based index of the column in the CSV file with the column name or -1 if is not one of the column names in the CSV file.

member.name: M:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvRecord.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an IEnumerator<KeyValuePair<string, string?>> to iterate over the object. The KeyValuePair<string, string?> contains the column name as and the content of the column as .
member.returns: An IEnumerator<KeyValuePair<string, string?>>.

member.name: T:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvWriter
member.summary: Writes data to a CSV file.
member.remarks: provides in the property a object, which represents a buffer for a data record (row) of the CSV file. Fill the object with - data and write it to the CSV file using the method. The method sets all fields from back to null values when it returns ​​so that the object can be filled again. If data types other than are to be written, the use of the class offers a convenient adapter between the data of the application and the CSV file.

example.note: In the following code examples - for easier readability - exception handling has been omitted.
example.para: Saving the contents of a as a CSV file and importing data from a CSV file into a :

member.name: F:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.CsvWriter.NewLine
member.summary: The newline sequence to use when writing CSV files ("\r\n").

member.summary: Initializes a new object with the column names for the header row to be written.
member.param: The file path of the CSV file to be written. If the file exists, it will be overwritten.

An array of column names for the header to be written. If the array contains null values these are replaced by automatically generated column names. Column names cannot appear twice. It is to note that the comparison is not case-sensitive - unless this option is explicitely chosen in .
Options for the CSV file to be written.
The text encoding to be used or null for .
The field separator char to use in the CSV file.
member.exception: is null.

exception.para: is not a valid file path
a column name in occurs twice. In you can choose, whether the comparison of column names is case-sensitive.

member.exception: I/O-Error.

member.name: T:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.Helpers.CsvAnalyzer
member.summary: can perform a statistical analysis on a CSV file and make the results available as object properties.

example.note: In the following code example - for easier readability - exception handling has been omitted.
example.para: Deserialization of any objects from CSV files:

member.name: F:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.Helpers.CsvAnalyzer.AnalyzedLinesMinCount
member.summary: Minimum number of lines in the CSV file to be analyzed.

member.name: M:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.Helpers.CsvAnalyzer.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new object.

member.name: M:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.Helpers.CsvAnalyzer.Analyze(System.String,System.Int32,System.Text.Encoding)
member.summary: Analyzes the CSV file referenced by and fills the properties of the object with the Results of the analysis.
member.param: File path of the CSV file.

Maximum number of lines to analyze in the CSV file. The minimum value is . If the file has fewer lines than it is completely analyzed. (You can specify Int32.MaxValue to ensure, that the entire file is analyzed.)
The text encoding to be used to read the CSV file or null for .
member.exception: is null.
is not a valid file path.
Error accessing the disk.

remarks.para: performs a statistical analysis on the CSV file to determine the appropriate parameters for reading the file. The result of the analysis is therefore always only an estimate. The accuracy of the analysis increases with the number of lines analyzed.
The analysis is time-consuming, because the CSV file has to be read-accessed.

member.summary: The field separator character used in the CSV file.

member.summary: Represents a property that implements dynamically at runtime ("late binding"). encapsulates information about access and type conversion, which needs to access the data of the underlying object.

member.summary: Maximum time (in milliseconds) that can be used to resolve a column name alias.

member.name: M:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.Helpers.CsvProperty.#ctor(System.String,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.String},FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.Helpers.Converters.ICsvTypeConverter,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new object.
member.param: The identifier, under which the property is addressed. It must follow the rules for identifiers. Only ASCII characters are accepted.

Column names of the CSV file, which can access. For the access uses the first alias, which is a match with a column name of the CSV file. The alias strings may contain the wildcard characters * and ?. When a wildcard alias matches several columns in the CSV file, the column with the lowest index is referenced.
The , which does the type conversion.

Timeout value in milliseconds or 0, for . If the value is greater than it is normalized to this value. If an alias in contains wildcard characters, inside this timeout the program tries to resolve the alias. If this does not succeed, reacts as if it had no target in the columns of the CSV file. (No timeout is used in .NET-Framework 4.0.)
member.exception: , or , or is null.
does not conform to the rules for C# identifiers (only ASCII characters).
is less than 0.

member.name: P:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.Helpers.CsvProperty.PropertyName
member.summary: Identifier of the property

member.name: P:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.Helpers.CsvProperty.ColumnNameAliases
member.summary: Collection of alternative column names of the CSV file, which is used by to access a column of .

remarks.para: In order to be compatible with different CSV files, e.g., different spellings of the same column name, or translations of the column name into other languages can be specified. An alias can also contain the wildcard characters * and ?.
Since all aliases are taken into account when setting the value of , it is not recommended to assign the same alias to several objects.

member.name: T:FolkerKinzel.CsvTools.Helpers.CsvRecordWrapper
member.summary: The class forms a wrapper around objects of the class , which enables you to index the data of the object in a sequence of your choice, to access the data with properties dynamically implemented at runtime, and to perform type conversions. In order to be able to use the dynamically implemented properties of the class ("late binding") directly and to assign the return values of the indexers without a cast, the instance of must be assigned to a variable that is declared with the keyword dynamic.

remarks.para: After a object has been initialized the method has to be called to register objects, which are dynamic properties of the object and perform type conversions for the s in the underlying object. The order in which the properties are registered determines the order, in which the return values ​​of these properties are returned if the object is iterated in a foreach loop, or if it is accessed with the indexer . Because of the objects access the underlying object via the CSV column name, the number and order of the objects registered in the object don't have to match the column-order of the underlying object.
The order of the registered properties can be influenced at any time with the following methods:
With you can check whether a object with the specified name is already registered.

The indexers , and can also be accessed if the instance is assigned to a normal variable, but the the values returned by the indexers possibly have to be cast into the actual data type with the cast operator since they are of the type .

If the instance is assigned to a variable that has been declared with the keyword dynamic, the runtime takes over the necessary casts. In addition, it is then possible to address the registered objects like normal properties by their name (). The disadvantage is that Visual Studio cannot offer any "IntelliSense" on dynamic variables.
If a CSV file is written with it is sufficient to assign the object only once, since when writing data always the same object is used.

When reading a CSV file with it behaves differently: With each iteration of the reader the current object must first be assigned to , because returnes a new with each iteration. (This does not apply, if the has been initialized with .)

example.note: In the following code examples - for easier readability - exception handling has been omitted.
example.para: Saving the contents of a as a CSV file and importing data from a CSV file into a :
